thread.title: NASA's Hubble sees spiral in Andromeda
thread.title_full: NASA's Hubble sees spiral in Andromeda

title: NASA's Hubble sees spiral in Andromeda
text:
NASA's Hubble sees spiral in Andromeda   Sunday, February 12, 2017 - 00:24   The US space agency NASA has released a beautiful image of galaxy known as NGC 7640. 
According to NASA, the Andromeda constellation is one of the 88 modern constellations and should not be confused with our neighboring Andromeda Galaxy. And it is home to the pictured galaxy known as NGC 7640. 
Though many different classifications have been used to identify galaxies by shape and structure, but NGC 7640 is a barred spiral type. These are recognizable by their spiral arms, which fan out not from a circular core, but from an elongated bar cutting through the galaxy’s center. 
Our home galaxy, the Milky Way, is also a barred spiral galaxy. Galaxy NGC 7640 might not look much like a spiral in the image because of the orientation of the galaxy with respect to Earth — or to Hubble, which acted as photographer in this case! 
We often do not see galaxies face on, which can make features such as spiral arms less obvious. 
As per reports, there is evidence that NGC 7640 has experienced some kind of interaction in its past. Galaxies contain vast amounts of mass, and therefore affect one another via gravity. Sometimes these interactions can be mild, and sometimes hugely dramatic, with two or more colliding and merging into a new, bigger galaxy. Understanding the history of a galaxy, and what interactions it has experienced, helps astronomers to improve their understanding of how galaxies — and the stars within them — form. First Published: Sunday, February 12, 2017 - 00:24 More from zeenews
